Award.AwardTitle: Development of Freeze-Shoe Sampler to Recover Aquifer Sands with In-situ Groundwater From up to 1000-ft Depth
Award.AbstractNarration:
1160753
van Geen

This grant supports development of new drilling and sampling technology to recover uncompromised aquifer sediment simultaneously with groundwater and to make this technology available to the scientific community under the auspices of the International Continental Scientific Drilling Program (ICDP). The development engages an academic-private partnership to build and test a prototype Peltier cooler based freeze core system designed to recover in situ, unconsolidated aquifer matrix and fluids to depths of 300 m for subsequent geochemical and sedimentological analysis. Upon completion of the development, the freeze core system will be deployed in a ICDP-funded project to study the provenance and redox controlled geochemical processes associated with the subsurface transport and fate of arsenide species and ultimately would be available to the broader science community for groundwater geochemical and microbiological investigations globally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to modify existing scientific drilling tools in a way that not only aquifer sediment but also pore fluids can be recovered from up to 300 m depth. After exploring several alternatives, the team opted for using liquid carbon dioxide as a cooling source for freezing the tip of a sediment core in situ - hereby essentially forming a hermetic seal at the bottom before recovering the core at the surface. A prototype was manufactured and tested to a depth of about 50 ft. The tests were successful in the sense that frozen sand was recovered. However, the center section of the core was not sufficiently frozen.  In addition, the prototype became detached from the drill string after a subsequent deployment and adapting the on-board software that controls a liquid carbon dioxide valve to cause more freezing. A new prototype was built and will be deployed again to a maximum depth of 1000 ft in 2016, with funding received from a separate source. If this deployment is succesful, NSF support will have generated new drilling technology with a wide range of potential applications - scientific and commercial - herewith addressing the "Intellectual Merit" criterion.  If this deployment is successful, and subsequent funding is obtained from other sources to deploy the technology in South and South Asia,  NSF support will have also have a considerably "Broader Impact" on society.  The new drilling tool is uniquely suited to evaluate the vulnerability of deep groundwater aquifers in the region to contamination with shallow groundwater containing toxic levels of arsenic - a public health issue affecting over 100 million rural inhabitants of the region.
